page.title: Comparison of Star Trek and Star Wars

revision.comment: /* Notable commentaries favoring one franchise over the other */
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:Comparison of ''Star Trek'' and ''Star Wars''}} Fans and scholars of '''''[[Star Trek]]''''', owned by [[CBS Television Studios]], and '''''[[Star Wars]]''''', owned by the [[Lucasfilm]] division of [[The Walt Disney Company]], compare the [[Media franchise|franchises']] merits while [[merchandising|merchandisers]] compete to sell rival products.<ref name="forbes">{{cite web|url=http://www.forbes.com/business/2005/05/16/cx_de_0516match.html|title=Star Wars Vs. Star Trek|accessdate=2007-09-13 |author=[[David M. Ewalt]]|date=2005-05-18|publisher=[[Forbes]]}}</ref> Media critics and analysts have compared and contrasted the two works in particular because of their great impact and similarities. The franchises are both large bodies of work that make up billions of dollars of [[intellectual property]], providing work and [[entertainment]] for millions of people.<ref name=HC>{{citation|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=130035|title=Trekkers VS Lucasites|date=May 14, 1999|author=Richard Ho|work=[[The Harvard Crimson]]}}</ref>
==Background== {{expand section|date=June 2014}} * Star Trek was first introduced as a television series going back to the mid and late 1960s. With the publication of novels, comics, animated series, toys and feature films, it grew into a full scale [[media franchise]]. Before that it was simply a television serial and known only as such that lasted only three seasons.
* Star Wars was first introduced as a feature film in cinema going back to the late 1970s, when the first film, ''Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope'', came out in 1977; though a novelization based on the film's earlier script was published a year before the film.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} Star Wars quickly grew into a popular media franchise shortly after the release of the first two films and novels.
==Differences== * ''Star Trek'' has its origin in television and was only known as a television series. The franchise was conceived in the style of the television Western ''[[Wagon Train]]'' and the adventure stories of [[Horatio Hornblower]] but adopted in the idealistic, [[utopia|utopian]] prospect of future human [[society]]. Star Trek's main focus is giving a fictional depiction of space exploration and the system of a galactic society consisting of multiple planets and species. Conflict occasionally occurs.
* ''Star Wars'' is an epic [[space opera]] was inspired by works such as [[Beowulf]] and [[King Arthur]], and the origins of myth and world religions.<ref name=Dreams>''Empire of Dreams: The Story of the Star Wars Trilogy''. Star Wars Trilogy Box Set DVD documentary. [2005]</ref> Star Wars is a story that depicts a galactic society in constant conflict. Though there are periods of peace, this is not documented in the feature films but can be found in the comics and novels and spin-off films.
==Similarities== {{expand section|date=June 2014}} Aside from having the word 'Star' in their respective titles, the two franchises also share many similarities:
* Both stories depict societies consisting of multiple planets and species. The main galaxy in Star Trek consists of various planets, both human and non-human, united into a single state known as the [[United Federation of Planets]]. Star Wars depicts a galaxy that is mostly part of a single state known as the [[Star Wars: The Old Republic|Old Republic]], inhabited by both humans and countless other species, that later became the [[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|Galactic Empire]] and later reformed into a new society called the [[New Republic (Star Wars)|New Republic]].
* Both franchises promote philosophical and political messages, though Star Wars not as much as Star Trek. The main philosophies of Star Trek convey the ethics of exploration and interference and how to morally deal with a new situation when faced by it. Creator Gene Roddenberry was inspired by stories like ''[[Gulliver's Travels]]'' that implied a [[morality play|morality tale]].<ref>See [[David Alexander]], "Star Trek Creator. The Authorized Biography of Gene Roddenberry" and interview with Roddenberry in "Something about the Author" by Gale Research Company and chapter 11 of "Trash Culture: Popular Culture and the Great Tradition" by Richard Keller Simon</ref> The main philosophical messages in Star Wars are the ethics of good against evil and how to distinguish one from the other. The philosophy of Star Wars also preaches against the totalitarian system and preaches in favor of societies that give equality to citizens.
* In January 2013, it was announced that [[J. J. Abrams]], director of ''[[Star Trek (film)|Star Trek]]'' (2009) and ''[[Star Trek Into Darkness]]'' (2013), had signed on to direct ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens|Star Wars Episode VII]]'' for [[Walt Disney Pictures]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/movies/article/jj-abrams-set-direct-next-star-wars-film-exclusive-74596 |title=J.J. Abrams Set to Direct Next 'Star Wars' Film (Exclusive) |author=Lucas Shaw |date=2013-01-24 |work=The Wrap}}</ref>
* There have been few actors who appeared in films of both franchises.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}
==Financial comparisons== {{empty-section|date=November 2014}}
==Notable commentaries favoring one franchise over the other== {{expand-section|date=November 2014}} * In the book ''Star Wars vs. Star Trek'' [[Tim Russ]] who played [[Tuvok]] on ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'' argues that while both franchises are spectacular, Star Trek comes out better than Star Wars because it has a setting in humanity's future and can connect with the audience better. Russ further goes to acknowledge that former role as a Star Trek character could be a factor in such judgements.<ref>Star Wars vs. Star Trek By Matt Forbeck</ref>
==Influences on one another== * The two franchises nonetheless have a "symbiotic relationship", states [[William Shatner]], who credits ''Star Wars'' for the beginning of the [[Star Trek (film franchise)|''Star Trek'' films]].<ref name="dominguez19990517">{{cite news | url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1999-05-17/entertainment/18105136_1_star-trek-memories-william-shatner-convention-speaker | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20120112134840/http://articles.nydailynews.com/1999-05-17/entertainment/18105136_1_star-trek-memories-william-shatner-convention-speaker | archivedate=2012-01-12 | title=William Shatner's Trek Never Ends The Actor-author Keeps Seeking New Challenges While Feeding Fans' Hunger For All Things Kirk | work=New York Daily News | date=1999-05-17 | accessdate=October 14, 2011 | author=Dominguez, Robert}}</ref> The documentary ''[[Trek Nation]]'' features interviews where both [[George Lucas]] and [[Gene Roddenberry]] praise one another's respective franchises, with the former stating that ''Star Trek'' was an influence while writing the original screenplay for ''Star Wars''.
==Criticism of both franchises== * Star Wars has been repeatedly criticized by various people for what they see as its violent nature and its mythical portrayal as "a contradiction of religious values".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capalert.com/capreports/starwarsstudy.htm|title=SPECIAL COMPARATIVE STUDY - STAR WARS: ChildCare Action Project (CAP) Media Analysis Report MAR07599|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="decentfilms.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.decentfilms.com/articles/starwarsissues|title=Star Wars: Moral and Spiritual Issues|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> In a two page essay Steve Johnson, a contributor for the [[Chicago Tribune]], gave his perception that "Star Wars is overrated".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-05-31/entertainment/ct-ae-0602-johnson-star-wars-20130531_1_naboo-millennium-falcon-star-wars|title=Star Wars overrated: May the Force be dissipated|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> A guest critic on Decent Films Guide raised many issues he feels that Star Wars poses, especially around its growing commerce as well as other issues regarding morality and violence.<ref name="decentfilms.com"/>
* Star Trek has been criticized by academics, journalists, critics and fans for its promotion of [[pseudoscience]].<ref>On Learning Science and Pseudoscience from Prime-Time Television Programming By Christopher Henry Whittle</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xibalba.demon.co.uk/jbr/trek/1.html|title=Star Trek: Mark Two (JBR Mega‐rant – 1)|author=Justin B Rye|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref><ref>Encyclopedia of Pseudoscience: From Alien Abductions to Zone Therapy edited by William F. Williams</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cracked.com/funny-8446-5-revolutionary-discoveries-in-star-trek-next-generation-that-were-completely-overlooked/|title=5 Revolutionary Discoveries In Star Trek: The Next Generation That Were Completely Overlooked|work=Cracked.com|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref><ref>Pseudoscience and Extraordinary Claims of the Paranormal: A Critical Thinker By Jonathan C. Smith</ref> [[David Kushner]] is a journalist and author who has written for various publications, including ''[[The New York Times]]''. He has been critical of the use of pseudoscience in Hollywood and criticized Star Trek for this reason.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/geek-life/tools-toys/the-science-of-pseudoscience|title=The Science of Pseudoscience|publisher=|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref> Author ''Mark Juddary'' in his book ''Overrated: The 50 Most Overhyped Things in History'' includes Star Trek amongst the list.<ref>Overrated: The 50 Most Overhyped Things in History</ref>
==Comic relief== * William Shatner was a presenter at George Lucas' AFI Lifetime Achievement Award ceremony. In 2011, ''Star Wars'' actress [[Carrie Fisher]] and Shatner posted a series of humorous YouTube videos [[satire|satirizing]] each other's franchises.
==Future== Both franchises are set to grow in the next few years.
* Star Trek was rebooted with a series of feature films started in 2009 which was followed by a [[Star Trek: Into Darkness|sequel]] in 2013 and a number of sequels set to follow.
* Star Wars is set to continue by storyline from where ''[[Return of the Jedi]]'' left off and is begin aimed to be at least a [[Star Wars sequel trilogy|sequel trilogy]] of films before the decision to make more films has been accepted.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.starwars.com/ Official ''Star Wars'' website] * [http://www.startrek.com/ Official ''Star Trek'' website]

{{Other uses|MECO (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Meco | image = | caption = | image_size = 175 | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = Domenico Monardo | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1939|11|29|mf=y}} |birth_place =[[Johnsonburg, Pennsylvania]], [[United States]]{{Cite book | last = Bronson | first = Fred | title = The Billboard Book of Number 1 Hits | publisher = Billboard Books | year = 2003 | pages = 474 | isbn = 0-8230-7677-6}} | death_date = | origin = | instrument = [[Trombone]] | genre = [[Space disco]], [[disco]], [[funk]], [[easy listening]] | occupation = [[Musician]], [[Arrangement|music arranger]], [[record producer]] | years_active = ca 1960–1985 | label = [[Millennium Records]], [[Casablanca Records]], [[RCA Records]], [[Hip-O Records|Hip-O]]/[[MCA Records]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Meco''' (real name '''Domenico Monardo'''; born November 29, 1939) is an [[United States|American]] [[record producer]] and [[musician]], as well as the name of a band or production team based around him. Meco is best known for his 1977 [[space disco]] version of the [[Star Wars Theme/Cantina Band|''Star Wars'' theme]] from his [[album]] ''[[Star Wars and Other Galactic Funk]]''; both the [[single (music)|single]] and album were [[RIAA certification|certified platinum]] in the U.S. ==Biography== Meco Monardo was born in [[Johnsonburg, Pennsylvania]], to parents of Italian descent, and building model ships, science fiction and movies were some of his boyhood preoccupations. His father played the [[valve trombone]] in a small Italian band, and through him Meco got his first musical education. Meco wanted to play the drums, but his father convinced him that the trombone was the right instrument, and at nine that was the instrument with which he was to stay. However, for Meco, the [[slide trombone]] was his choice, troublesome as it was for the small-statured boy to extend the slide fully at first. He joined the [[School band#High school bands|high school band]] while still attending elementary school. At 17, he won a scholarship to the [[Eastman School of Music]] in [[Rochester, New York]], which provided him with a solid [[classical music|classical]] and [[jazz]] music education. There, together with his two friends [[Chuck Mangione]] and [[Ron Carter]], he started the Eastman School of Music [[jazz band|Jazz Band]]. When he enrolled at [[West Point]], he also played in the Cadet Band. Out of the army Meco moved to [[New York City]] and joined [[Kai Winding]] in his four-trombone band, and then from 1965 to 1974 he went on as a [[studio musician]]. Originally not inclined toward pop music, Meco's heart changed when he heard [[Petula Clark]]'s "[[Downtown (Petula Clark song)|Downtown]]." He began doing [[arrangement]]s, for example the [[horn section]] on [[Tommy James]]' "[[Crystal Blue Persuasion]]" and the [[Neil Diamond]] series of [[Coca-Cola|Coke]] commercials. As a [[session musician]] he played the trombone with acts like [[Tommy James]], [[Diana Ross]], and [[David Barretto]]. Although Meco focused on producing in the late 1970s, he contracted the horns and performed on Diana Ross' 1980 album ''[[Diana (album)|Diana]]'' as a favor to producer (and neighbor) [[Nile Rodgers]]. His solo on the single "[[I'm Coming Out]]" is notable because of the rarity of [[trombone]] features on post-big-band era pop records.[http://www.comicgenius.com/DISCOFEVER/disco_profiles/meco/meco_profile.htm Disco Profiles: Meco – The Funk is With Him] [[File:Mecologo.png|thumb|right|220px|The uniquely styled Meco logo]] Around 1973, Meco, [[Tony Bongiovi]], and a third person formed the production company Disco Corporation of America, and, from 1974 to 1976, Meco worked as a record producer. The team of Meco, Bongiovi, Jay Ellis, and [[Harold Wheeler (musician)|Harold Wheeler]] produced the 1974 [[Gloria Gaynor]] hit "[[Never Can Say Goodbye]]." [[Carol Douglas]]' "[[Doctor's Orders (song)|Doctor's Orders]]" was among the other productions of that period. According to Meco:
"When disco was new, it was fresh and exciting because it was different. But pretty soon it became too cookie-cutter and wore itself out."
Meco temporarily left the music industry in 1985. After three years of "doing nothing but playing [[golf]]" he started to work as a [[commodity broker]] in Florida. ==''Star Wars'' theme== [[File:Mecoband.JPG|thumb|right|The "Sci-Fi Disco Band MECO" in 1977]] On Wednesday May 25, 1977, Meco watched the [[20th Century-Fox]] soon-to-be blockbuster hit ''[[Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope|Star Wars]]'' on its opening day. By Thursday night, he had seen the film four more times, and attended several more screenings over the weekend. In the days before cable, computers, video cassettes and DVDs/Blu-rays, other than waiting for it to be broadcast on network television, this was the only way someone could see a movie. He then got the idea to make a disco version of the score by [[John Williams]] and contacted [[Neil Bogart]] at [[Casablanca Records]] to pitch the project. Only after both the picture itself as well as the original score had become huge hits did Bogart agree to help Meco realize his idea. Contact was established with [[Millennium Records]], then a Casablanca subsidiary, and this became Meco's first record company. Here Meco rejoined with Tony Bongiovi as well as [[Harold Wheeler (musician)|Harold Wheeler]] who had also been part of the team behind "Never Can Say Goodbye" in 1974. Lance Quinn was also part of the Meco team, and the different roles played by the four musicians is described by Meco himself in a 1999 interview with his fan Web site: {{cquote|Tony and Lance are the two guys who would not let me be "too musical". Tony would say: "It's not dumb enough—It's too good." Tony is a frustrated drummer and Lance is a guitar genius, so they would make sure the rhythm section was always "smoking" under the very sophisticated arrangements and concepts that Harold and I started with.{{cite web |url= http://www.geocities.com/mecofan/?200711 |title= 1999 interview with the Mecofan Page |accessdate=2007-12-11 |format= |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/mecofan/%3F200711&date=2009-10-26+02:27:40|archivedate=2009-10-26}}}} In a matter of just three weeks they arranged and recorded ''[[Star Wars and Other Galactic Funk]]''. Although the album was nominated for "Best Instrumental Pop performer" in 1977, the award ultimately went to John Williams for the original soundtrack album. ==The band Meco== For a period of four months there was even a show band assembled to perform to Meco's disco music in public venues. However, the band was not involved in the making of the music. This initiative was organized by Norby Walters, a booking agent for discos. The band members (pictured in this article) toured the U.S. and Canada as a high energy show band called '''Lemon Tree'''. Norby Walters booked and also managed the band before the Star Wars project. Band personnel was Carmine Giovinazzo, Stan Glogicheski, Tommy Rocco, Tony Abruzzo, and Tony "Butch" Gerace. ==Other soundtracks become "Meco-ized"== In the fall of 1977, Meco's second album was released. It was another rearranged science-fiction movie soundtrack, ''[[Encounters Of Every Kind]]'', based on John Williams music of the movie ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'', from which three singles were released: "Topsy," "Meco's Theme," and "Theme from ‘Close Encounters.’" Meco's third album came in early 1978, and this time it was the [[Musical selections in The Wizard of Oz|music from]] ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard Of Oz]]'', which got transformed into a disco album by the same name, as Meco described: "It is my best work, bar none." From this album came the [[chart-topper|hit single]] "Themes from The Wizard of Oz: ‘Over the Rainbow’/‘We're off to See the Wizard.’" In the fall of 1978, Millennium merged with [[RCA Records|RCA]]. Since he had developed a deep-bonded working relationship with Neil Bogart and other staff at Casablanca Records (Millennium and Casablanca having cooperated closely), Meco decided to move to Casablanca. Casablanca released the fourth Meco album, ''Superman & Other Galactic Heroes'', featuring two hit singles, "Superman Theme" and "Love Theme From Superman." This was yet another Meco makeover of an original John Williams score. In 1979, the fifth album, ''Moondancer'', was released, and with it the hit singles "Moondancer," "[[Grazing In The Grass]]," and "Devil's Delight." In 1980, Meco's sixth album, ''Music From “Star Trek” & Music from “The Black Hole,”'' was released, featuring the song "Theme From ‘Star Trek.’" The movie ''[[Star Trek: The Motion Picture]]'' ([[1979 in film|1979]]) featured an original soundtrack composed by [[Jerry Goldsmith]]. The last album that Meco made for Casablanca, his seventh, which came out in 1981, was ''The American Werewolf In London'', based on the soundtrack from the 1981 movie ''[[An American Werewolf in London]]''. After this Meco's tenure with Casablanca was over, and he signed with [[RCA Records]]. ==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''[[Star Wars and Other Galactic Funk]]'' (1977) * ''[[Encounters Of Every Kind]]'' (1977) * ''[[Meco Plays The Wizard of Oz]]'' (1978) * ''[[Superman & Other Galactic Heroes]]'' (1978) * ''Moondancer'' (1979) * ''Meco Plays Music from The Empire Strikes Back'' ([[Extended play|10" EP]] – 1980) * ''[[Christmas in the Stars|Christmas In The Stars: Star Wars Christmas Album]]'' (1980) * ''Music From Star Trek and Music From The Black Hole'' (1980) * ''Across The Galaxy'' (1980) * ''The American Werewolf In London'' (1981) * ''Pop Goes The Movies'' (1982) * ''Swingtime's Greatest Hits'' (1982) * ''Ewok Celebration'' (1983) * ''Hooked on Instrumentals'' (1985) * ''The Best of Meco'' (1997) * ''The Complete Star Wars Collection'' (2000) * ''Star Wars Party'' (2005) (This release is only sold on the Internet, a retail release with identical musical content was released as ''Music Inspired by “Star Wars”'') ===Singles=== ====Charted singles==== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Year ! Song Title ! Artist Credit ! ''Billboard''
[[Hot 100]]

Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin: Record Research Inc., 1991. ==External links== *[http://www.discogs.com/artist/Meco+Monardo Meco Discography] *[http://www.discomusic.com/people-more/39_0_11_0_C Meco Monardo interview] with DiscoMusic.com *[http://www.oocities.org/mecofan/main.html The Official MECO Fan Page] This Page is an outdated, user-generated website brought to you by an archive.It was mirrored from GeoCities at end October, 2009. *[http://www.disco-disco.com/tributes/meco.shtml Meco fanpage] {{Authority control|VIAF=63209920}} {{Persondata | NAME = Meco | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American musician | DATE OF BIRTH = 29 November 1939 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Johnsonburg, Pennsylvania]] [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American disco musicians]] [[Category:American jazz trombonists]] [[Category:American people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Musicians from Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American record producers]] [[Category:American music arrangers]] [[Category:People from Elk County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American musicians]] [[Category:Star Wars]]

''This article is about the trilobite. For the character in Star Wars, see'' [[Han Solo]]. {{italictitle}}{{Taxobox | name = ''Han solo'' | fossil_range = {{fossil range|Middle Ordovician}} | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Arthropod]]a | classis = [[Trilobite|Trilobita]] | ordo = [[Agnostida]] | familia = [[Diplagnostidae]] | subfamilia = [[Pseudagnostinae]] | genus = '''''Han''''' | genus_authority = Turvey, 2005 | species = '''''H. solo''''' | binomial = ''Han solo'' | binomial_authority = Turvey, 2005 }} '''''Han''''' is a genus of [[agnostid]] [[trilobite]], whose sole member is '''''Han solo''''', a species known only from [[fossil]]s found in the [[Ordovician]] [[Zitai Formation]] of southern [[China]].
==Taxonomy== This taxon was erected in 2005, based upon fossil material found in beds of lower [[Zitai Formation]] exposed in [[Maocaopu]], [[Reshi]], [[Taoyuan County, Hunan|Taoyuan County]] in north [[Hunan]], [[China]]. Fossil material include a [[cephalon (trilobite anatomy)|cephalon]] and two [[pygidium|pygidia]]. It was found to belong to family [[Diplagnostidae]], subfamily [[Pseudagnostinae]]; it was originally thought to be most closely related to the genus ''[[Pseudorhaptagnostus]]'', but it differed substantially from that genus in both some important diagnostic characters, and in the age of the beds in it was deposited, so a new genus was erected.<ref name="Turvey 2005">{{cite journal | author = Samuel T. Turvey | year = 2005 | title = Agnostid trilobites from the Arenig–Llanvirn of South China | journal = [[Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]]: Earth Sciences | volume = 95 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 527–542 | url = http://journals.cambridge.org/production/action/cjoGetFulltext?fulltextid=1199796 | accessdate = February 9, 2009 | doi = 10.1017/S0263593304000355}}</ref>
==Etymology== According to the original publication, the generic name ''Han'' is a reference to the [[Han Chinese]], the largest [[ethnic group]] in present-day China; and the specific epithet ''solo'' refers to the fact that the species is the youngest [[Diplagnostidae]] fossil found to that date, suggesting that it was the last surviving member of that family.<ref name="Turvey 2005"/> However, Turvey has stated elsewhere that he named it after [[Han Solo]] because some friends dared him to name a species after a [[Star Wars]] character.<ref name="Curiosities">{{cite web | url = http://www.curioustaxonomy.net/etym/fiction.html | title = Etymology: Names from Fictional Characters | work = Curiosities of Biological Nomenclature | accessdate = February 5, 2009}}</ref>
This is not the only unusual scientific name erected by Turvey; in the same paper he named a new species of ''[[Geragnostus]]'' ''[[Geragnostus waldorfstatleri|G. waldorfstatleri]]'', because of "the resemblance of the pygidial axis to the heads of [[Waldorf and Statler]], two characters from ''[[The Muppet Show]]''."<ref name="Turvey 2005"/> The actor who portrays Han Solo in Star Wars, [[Harrison Ford]], also has a species of spider named for him, ''[[Calponia harrisonfordi]]''. [[Arachnologist]] [[Norman I. Platnick]] named it for him out of thanks for assistance in a museum film production. Other taxa named after Star Wars characters include the [[isopod]] ''[[Albunione yoda]]'', the [[Oribatida|oribatid]] [[mite]] genus ''[[Darthvaderum]]'', the [[wasp]]s ''[[Polemistus chewbacca]]'' and ''[[Polemistus vaderi]]'', and the [[beetle]] ''[[Agathidium vaderi]]''.<ref name="Curiosities"/>
==See also== *[[List of organisms named after famous people]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Agnostida]] [[Category:Fossil taxa described in 2005]] [[Category:Monotypic arthropod genera]] [[Category:Ordovician animals]] [[Category:Star Wars]]

Theme parks |otherdata1 = * [[Star Tours—The Adventures Continue]] * [[Star Tours]] * [[Star Wars Weekends#Jedi Training Academy|Jedi Training Academy]] }}
'''''Star Wars''''' is an American [[epic film|epic]] [[space opera]] franchise centered on a [[film series]] created by [[George Lucas]]. The film series, consisting of two trilogies (and an upcoming third), has spawned an extensive [[media franchise]] called the [[Star Wars Expanded Universe|Expanded Universe]] including [[List of Star Wars books|books]], television series, [[Star Wars video games|computer and video games]], and [[List of Star Wars comic books|comic books]]. These supplements to the franchise resulted in significant development of the series' [[fictional universe]], keeping the franchise active in the 16-year interim between the two film trilogies. The franchise depicts a galaxy described as far, far away in the distant past, and it commonly portrays [[Jedi]] as a representation of good, in conflict with the [[Sith]], their evil counterpart. Their weapon of choice, the [[lightsaber]], is commonly recognized in popular culture. The franchise's storylines contain many themes, with strong influences from [[Philosophy and religion in Star Wars|philosophy and religion]].
The first film in the series was originally released on May 25, 1977, under the title ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'', by [[20th Century Fox]], and became a worldwide [[popular culture|pop culture]] phenomenon, followed by two sequels, released at three-year intervals. Sixteen years after the release of the trilogy's final film, the first in a new [[prequel]] trilogy of films was released. The three prequel films were also released at three-year intervals, with the final film of the trilogy released on May 19, 2005. In 2012, [[The Walt Disney Company]] acquired [[Lucasfilm]] for $4.05 billion and announced that it would produce [[Star Wars sequel trilogy|three new films]], with the first film, ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]]'', planned for release in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://money.msn.com/business-news/article.aspx?feed=AP&Date=20121030&ID=15733883 |title= Disney to make new 'Star Wars' films, buy Lucas co | last= Nakashima | first = Ryan |work=MSN Money|date=October 30, 2012|accessdate=October 31, 2012}}</ref> 20th Century Fox still retains the distribution rights to the first two ''Star Wars'' trilogies, owning permanent rights for the original film ''Episode IV: A New Hope'', while holding the rights to ''Episodes I''–''III'', ''V'', and ''VI'' until May 2020.<ref name="FOXrights">{{cite web | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tangled-rights-could-tie-up-384541 | title=Tangled Rights Could Tie Up Ultimate 'Star Wars' Box Set (Analysis) | work =The Hollywood Reporter | date=October 30, 2012 | accessdate=November 12, 2012 | last =Masters | first = Kim}}</ref>
Reactions to the original trilogy were positive, with the last film being considered the weakest, while the prequel trilogy received a more mixed reaction, with most of the praise being for the final film, according to most [[review aggregator]] websites. All six of the main films in the series were nominated for or won [[Academy Awards]]. All of the main films have been box office successes, with the overall box office revenue generated by the ''Star Wars'' films (including the theatrical ''[[Star Wars: The Clone Wars (film)|Star Wars: The Clone Wars]]'') totalling $4.38 billion,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/series/StarWars.php | title = Star Wars – Box Office History | work = The numbers | accessdate= June 17, 2010}}</ref> making it the [[List of highest-grossing films#Highest-grossing franchises and film series|fifth-highest-grossing film series]].<ref name="Numbers franchises">{{cite web |title=Movie Franchises |work=The Numbers |publisher = Nash Information Services |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/series/franchisesW.php |accessdate=January 3, 2013}}</ref> The success has also led to multiple re-releases in theaters for the series.
==Setting== {{Redirect |Star Wars galaxy|the video game|Star Wars Galaxies|the comic series named ''Star Wars Galaxy''|Star Wars (UK comics)}} The events depicted in ''Star Wars'' media take place in a [[fictional galaxy]]. Many species of [[List of Star Wars creatures|alien creatures]] (often [[humanoid]]) are depicted. Robotic [[droid (robot)|droids]] are also commonplace and are generally built to serve their owners. [[Spacefaring|Space travel]] is common, and many planets in the galaxy are members of a [[Galactic Republic]], later reorganized as the [[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|Galactic Empire]].
One of the prominent elements of ''Star Wars'' is the "[[Force (Star Wars)|Force]]", an omnipresent energy that can be harnessed by those with that ability, known as Force-sensitives. It is described in the first produced film as "an energy field created by all living things [that] surrounds us, penetrates us, [and] binds the galaxy together."<ref name="star wars 4">{{Cite video|title=[[Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope]]|publisher=[[20th Century Fox]]|date=2006|medium=DVD}}</ref> The Force allows users to perform various [[supernatural]] feats (such as [[Psychokinesis|telekinesis]], [[clairvoyance]], [[precognition]], and [[mind control]]) and can amplify certain physical traits, such as speed and reflexes; these abilities vary between characters and can be improved through training. While the Force can be used for good, it has a [[Dark side (Star Wars)|dark side]] that, when pursued, imbues users with hatred, aggression, and malevolence. The six films feature the [[Jedi]], who use the Force for good, and the [[Sith]], who use the dark side for evil in an attempt to take over the galaxy. In the [[Star Wars Expanded Universe|''Star Wars'' Expanded Universe]], many dark side users are [[Dark Jedi]] rather than Sith, mainly because of the "[[Star Wars: Darth Bane: Rule of Two|Rule of Two]]" (see [[Sith#Sith characters|Sith Origin]]).<ref name="star wars 4" /><ref name="star wars 1">{{Cite video| title= [[Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace]] | publisher=[[20th Century Fox]]|date=2001|medium=DVD}}</ref><ref name="star wars 2" /><ref name="star wars 3" /><ref name="star wars 5">{{Cite video | title =[[Star Wars Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back]]|publisher=[[20th Century Fox]]|date=2004|medium=DVD}}</ref><ref name="star wars 6">{{Cite video|title = [[Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi]]|publisher=[[20th Century Fox]]|date=2004|medium= DVD}}</ref>
==Theatrical films== The film series began with ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'', released on May 25, 1977. This was followed by two sequels: ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]'', released on May 21, 1980, and ''[[Return of the Jedi]]'', released on May 25, 1983. The [[Star Wars opening crawl|opening crawl]] of the sequels disclosed that they were numbered as "Episode V" and "Episode VI" respectively, though the films were generally advertised solely under their subtitles. Though the first film in the series was simply titled ''Star Wars'', with its 1981 re-release it had the subtitle ''Episode IV: A New Hope'' added to remain consistent with its sequel, and to establish it as the middle chapter of a continuing saga.<ref name = "Lucas">{{Cite video| people=Lucas, George|date=2004|title=DVD commentary for Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope|medium=DVD|publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref>
In 1997, to correspond with the 20th anniversary of ''A New Hope'', Lucas released a "Special Edition" of the ''Star Wars'' trilogy to theaters. The re-release featured alterations to the three films, primarily motivated by the improvement of [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] and other special effects technologies, which allowed visuals that were not possible to achieve at the time of the original filmmaking. Lucas continued to [[list of changes in Star Wars re-releases|make changes]] to the films for subsequent releases, such as the first ever [[DVD]] release of the original trilogy on September 21, 2004 and the first ever [[Blu-ray]] release of all six films on September 16, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=March 28, 2008|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-56847187.html|title=The Force returns: ‘Star Wars' Special Edition features some new tinkering but same old thrills | work= The Washington Times |date= January 26, 1997| last = Arnold | first = Gary}}</ref> Reception of the ''Special Edition'' was mixed,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Utichi|first1=Joe|title=Star Wars on Blu-ray: George, don't do that…|url=http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2010/aug/19/star-wars-blu-ray-lucas|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=July 27, 2014|date=August 19, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Will Disney Ever Release the original pre-Special Edition Star Wars Movies?|url=http://thestarwarstrilogy.com/starwars/post/2014/02/17/Will-Disney-Ever-Release-the-original-pre-Special-Edition-Star-Wars-Movies|publisher=The Star Wars Trilogy|accessdate=July 27, 2014|date=February 17, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope – Comparison: Special Edition, DVD Edition|url=http://www.movie-censorship.com/report.php?ID=2601599|publisher=Movie-Censorship.com|accessdate=July 27, 2014|date=January 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Hutchinson|first1=Lee|title=Could Disney finally give us the remastered, unedited Star Wars we want?|url=http://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2014/05/could-disney-finally-give-us-the-remastered-unedited-star-wars-we-want/|publisher=ARS Technica|accessdate=July 27, 2014|date=May 10, 2014}}</ref> prompting petitions and fan edits to produce restored copies of the original trilogy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Request to Restore the Theatrical Cuts of the Original Star Wars Trilogy for Blu-ray|url=http://originaltrilogy.com/petition/|publisher=OriginalTrilogy.com|accessdate=July 27, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Philippe|first1=Alexandre O.|url=http://peoplevsgeorge.com/|publisher=The People vs. George Lucas|accessdate=July 27, 2014|title=The People vs. George Lucas}}</ref>
More than two decades after the release of the original film, the series continued with a prequel trilogy; consisting of ''[[Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace|Episode I: The Phantom Menace]]'', released on May 19, 1999; ''[[Star Wars Episode II: Attack of the Clones|Episode II: Attack of the Clones]]'', released on May 16, 2002; and ''[[Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith|Episode III: Revenge of the Sith]]'', released on May 19, 2005.<ref name="release dates">{{cite web|accessdate=March 27, 2008|url=http://www.starwars.com/episode-iii/bts/production/news20040405.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415144223/http://www.starwars.com/episode-iii/bts/production/news20040405.html|archivedate=April 15, 2008|title=Episode III Release Dates Announced|publisher=Star Wars|date=April 5, 2004}}</ref> On August 15, 2008, ''[[Star Wars: The Clone Wars (film)|Star Wars: The Clone Wars]]'' was released theatrically as a lead-in to the weekly [[Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008 TV series)|animated TV series of the same name]]. ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]]'' is scheduled for release on December 18, 2015. In 2013, it was announced the original ''Star Wars'' film will be the first [[Hollywood]] film to be dubbed into [[Navajo language|Navajo]].<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Star-Wars-translated-into-Navajo/tabid/418/articleID/295833/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Star Wars translated into Navajo| date=April 29, 2013}}</ref>
